results.title: San Bernardino Suspects Spoke of Earlier Attack, F.B.I. Says
results.abstract: The F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, said Syed Rizwan Farook and Tashfeen Malik had talked of jihad and martyrdom before they started courting online.
results.byline: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and SALMAN MASOOD
org_facet: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

results.title: Enrique Marquez, Buyer of Guns Used in San Bernardino Attack, Is Studied
results.abstract: Mr. Marquez, who bought the assault rifles used in the rampage, was a neighbor of one of the attackers. Officials hope he holds clues about their thinking.
results.byline: By RICK ROJAS and IAN LOVETT

results.abstract: Robert L. Dear Jr., who was accused of 179 counts in court on Wednesday, disrupted the proceeding, at one point yelling, “I’m a warrior for the babies.”

results.title: New Chicago Police Video Prompts Rebuke From Mayor Rahm Emanuel
results.abstract: Footage showed a 38-year-old black man being shocked by a Taser and dragged down a jail hallway by officers in 2012. The man, Philip Coleman, later died.

results.title: Police Chiefs Say Scrutiny Over Videos Has Radically Changed Their Work
results.abstract: Some chiefs say that the public examination of fatal police shootings has made their jobs more difficult, far more political and much less secure.

results.title: Americans Who Don’t Buy Health Coverage Face Heftier Fine in ’16, Analysis Finds
results.abstract: Americans who remain uninsured in 2016 despite having the option of buying health coverage through an Affordable Care Act marketplace will owe an average tax penalty of $969 per household.
des_facet: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

results.title: Robert E. Macdonald Wins 3rd Term as Mayor of Lewiston, Maine
results.abstract: The race was a classic clash between generations and ideologies, and Ben Chin, an activist with a liberal alliance, substantially outspent the incumbent, Robert E. Macdonald.

results.title: Anxiety Grows in Texas With Syrians Due to Arrive Soon
results.abstract: The expected arrival of 21 of the refugees in the state this week has intensified concerns and fears about accepting Syrians in the wake of the Paris attacks last month.
results.byline: By MANNY FERNANDEZ and JULIA PRESTON

multimedia.caption: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas, left, and the state’s governor, Greg Abbott, talking about Mr. Cruz’s bill, the State Refugee Security Act, which requires 21 days’ notice for a state to resettle a refugee.

results.title: Americans Attracted to ISIS Find an ‘Echo Chamber’ on Social Media
results.abstract: As the White House takes on the challenge of the Islamic State, it is focusing on the online community of sympathizers in the United States, who number in the hundreds and fit no single profile.
results.byline: By SCOTT SHANE, MATT APUZZO and ERIC SCHMITT
org_facet: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

multimedia.caption: A collection of posts from Twitter accounts sympathetic to the Islamic State. Lions, a reference to warriors as “lions of Allah,” are a popular symbol. Some users praise the recent killings in San Bernardino, Calif., while others offer advice to prevent hacker groups like Anonymous from disabling pro-Islamic State accounts.

results.title: Tibor Rubin Is Dead at 86; Medal of Honor Was Delayed by Anti-Semitism
results.abstract: Corporal Rubin was a Hungarian-born American hero, who joined the United States Army to thank the nation and the troops that rescued him from a Nazi concentration camp.

multimedia.caption: Tibor Rubin, pictured in 1953, spent 30 months as a prisoner of war in North Korea. Fellow prisoners later testified about his willingness to sacrifice for the good of others.

results.title: Yale Lecturer Resigns After Email on Halloween Costumes
results.abstract: Erika Christakis, who had suggested there could be negative consequences to the university’s directive to be sensitive when choosing Halloween costumes, resigned from her position voluntarily, the school said.

results.title: How an Effort to Close Loopholes in California’s Assault Weapons Law Was Thwarted
results.abstract: Gov. Jerry Brown vetoed a 2013 bill that would have restricted the kind of semiautomatic rifles acquired by Syed Rizwan Farook and Tashfeen Malik, the suspects in the San Bernardino massacre.

results.abstract: The federal government is moving to open two shelters in Texas and one in California this month, adding at least 1,400 beds to handle the increased flow, senior Obama administration officials said.

results.title: San Bernardino County Offices Reopen After Shooting

results.title: Prompt Medical Care May Have Saved Freddie Gray, Experts Testify
results.abstract: A medical examiner who performed the autopsy on Mr. Gray said his death would not have been ruled a homicide if he had been driven to a hospital when Officer William G. Porter says he suggested so.

results.title: No Charges for Chicago Officer in 2014 Shooting of Ronald Johnson
results.abstract: The announcement followed several weeks of uproar in Chicago over charges for another officer in a separate shooting death, of Laquan McDonald.
results.byline: By MONICA DAVEY and MITCH SMITH

results.title: Yale Finds Error in Legal Stylebook: Harvard Did Not Create It
results.abstract: The Harvard Law Review has long claimed credit for creating The Bluebook, but a new article from two librarians at Yale Law School says the idea originated in New Haven.

multimedia.caption: The Harvard Law Review has long claimed credit for creating The Bluebook, a 582-page style manual formally known as “A Uniform System of Citation.”

results.abstract: The president appeared to use the 150th anniversary of the amendment abolishing slavery to challenge the anti-Muslim politics espoused by the Republican candidate.
